Authors:
Alice da Cruz Lima Gerlach, Zeynep Toprak, Yamama Naciri,
Elena Araujo Cavir√≥, Rosa Mara Borges da Silveira, Philippe Clerc
Title:
New insights into the Usnea cornuta aggregate (Parmeliaceae,
lichenized Ascomycota): molecular analysis reveals a high genetic
diversity correlated with chemistry
Keywords:
Coalescent model, lichen-forming fungi, parallel
evolution, protein-coding genes, STACEY, systematics, secondary
metabolites, thin-layer chromatography
Abstract:
Biological processes such as hybridization, incomplete
lineage sorting or gene flow can obscure the signals for the recognition
of evolutionary distinct lineages, in particular in groups of organisms
having diverged recently. Therefore, compiling pieces of evidence from
diverse sources of data may be critical for the accurate assessment of
species boundaries in such groups. The increasing availability of DNA
sequences data allows getting much deeper insight into the understanding
of diversification and speciation processes and their consequences on
the biodiversity. In this study, we applied an integrative approach
based on DNA sequences, chemical, geographic, and morphological data,
and attempted to define species boundaries in the lichen-forming genus
Usnea (Parmeliaceae), with a particular focus on the U. cornuta
aggregate, a cosmopolitan species group. We provide the first
multispecies coalescent (MSC) based species delimitation for this group
of Usnea species from the Neotropics. Based on ITS rDNA, and the two
protein-coding genes RPB1, and Mcm7, we estimated the species tree under
the MSC model in a Bayesian framework using STACEY. Our results indicate
that at least nine strongly supported distinct lineages coexist in the
U. cornuta aggregate, each of them being well chemically characterized.
We additionally found evidence for the polyphyly of three morphospecies,
Usnea brasiliensis, U. cornuta and U. dasaea.
